Series recap: Game of Thrones Season 4

22/06/2014

Gorier and more traumatic and confusing than ever, this series reached new and dizzying heights. Alex Killeen reviews

Image by

By James Bithell

Warning: this article contains spoilers. No one can deny that repeatedly the creators, cast, and crew that work on the Game of Thrones set are dedicated to cranking up the level each and every season. While the ending of the last season was competent in temporarily tying up events and storylines much was still to be resolved, probably due to the fact that these two seasons spanned the length of one book. So after the tumultuous events at the closing of the previous season, this season hinged on satisfactorily opening up those half-closed wounds and leading the series into new and dizzying heights. It's definitely been a hell of ride this time around and yet again, it's sad to see it go for another year. Fortunately this will once again leave us with some of the best moments of TV ever, if not the goriest, most traumatising, and confusing. Still, there was a lot in this series that made fans happy. A lot went on. We saw some excellent performances from a whole plethora of characters like Tyrion, Tywin, Arya and The Hound, Sansa, Theon, or Reek, and even Jon Snow. Game of Thrones came into it's own in this series focusing yet again on some extremely character-driven interactions that made the series feel like it never needs the gore or action to keep the flow of the show going. Some backstories on certain character like Tyrion and Jaime's cousin Orson, Oberyn's visit to the new born Tyrion, whose apparent monstrosity was particularly overplayed, Jorah's betrayal biting back at him when Daenerys discovers it, The Hound's traumatic childhood, and even smaller characters like Maester Aemon of the Night's Watch's first and only love. Once again, however, Game of Thrones was superb in its treatment of portraying the uncomfortable side of its medieval fantasy world. Jaime's rape of Cersei was one outstanding point that made for huge discomfort and outrage, and rightly so. But additionally, Oberyn's gruesome demise at the hands of The Mountain, Arya's developing ruthlessness and impaling of Polliver, Jon Snow's sword meeting the back of Karl's head and coming out of his mouth. Even the death of Joffrey was quite poignant and the emotional reaction of Cersei only made the disappointing end of his life sting evermore. Although much of this grotesque action could be confused for some of its more awesome set pieces: The Battle for Meereen, the Battle for the Wall, the actual fight preluding Oberyn's demise, The Hound and Brienne's brutal fight, the storm of Stannis' troops across Mance Ryder's forces. Overall, it reinforced the faith fans can have in the show's ability to both create amazing action and make us repulsed by it. Season Four's hyperbolic treatment of some parts of this action will undoubtedly leave us wanting more. Choreography, costuming, tone, and the musical score and all done to near perfection through much of the series and it's hard to fault it at certain points. Indeed, even the subtle character interactions made us swoon. There is something about discourse in this show that can make it almost as intense as the action. Tyrion and Joffrey's interaction prior to the latter's death, Sansa and her Aunt Lysa's arguments before the latter's death, heck even the small smile between Jon and Ygritte before the latter's death was amazing. There's a pattern there somewhere. But this isn't to mention the other great dialogue. Usually they say actions speak louder than words but if anything can show the exact opposite to this, it's Game of Thrones's characters. Some characters almost definitely came into their own in the season as well. Jon Snow, apart from still being a bit mopey, came across as the great leader he is destined to be and that at time he can be badass. Sansa is finally becoming the women of agency we've always wanted her to be. Indeed she may have a slight problem in the stalker tendencies of Petyr Baelish but at the same time we can see that new edge to her, one that's as manipulative and intelligent as the most superior character in the Game of Thrones mythos. Arya is developing well under the harsh tutelage of The Hound and their relationship was undoubtedly one of the best in the season, and even the programme, so far. Even Bran got a bit more exciting this time around. His storyline may be delving into the most supernatural elements we have seen yet but it felt like it was much needed. The next, penultimate paragraphs will discuss my favourite and will probably be the most spoiler-heavy so if you haven't seen it yet you should probably cease reading now. The Battle for the Wall was simply one of the most amazing pieces of action Game of Thrones has ever produced. Knowing that many of the battles from previous series have been downplayed due to budget problems, this was one of the only big battle they were capable of commissioning and it completely paid off. The whole affair was tense, brutal, and shocking to the end. One shot in particular grabbed my attention as the camera panned around from the centre of Castle Black's courtyard, focusing in on each of the main players in the battle. Particular credit goes to Tormund for being the embodiment of the fierce wildling we've always wanted to see. Tyrion's fall from grace deserves special praise. His speeches when on trial and when in the jail cells were simply staggering and his interactions with many of the characters from the Game of Thrones roster were nothing short of stunning. His conversation and separation from Bronn was probably the most powerful. Eventually however, for all of the mistreatment throughout his life and his condemnation culminated in the Episode 10 twist. When Tyrion is released but decides to confront his father, his discovery and subsequent murder of Shae was beautiful and heartbreaking. Her betrayal both from the trial and in the bedroom made me cheer but also take a moment to assess what Tyrion has been forced to become. His anger only carried on when he confronted his father, Tywin, and led to one of the most remarkable interactions I've seen for a very long time. This should probably get wrapped up now. But generally, and I know everyone says it at the end of a Game of Thrones series, this has been the most epic yet. Almost everything was divine, some things were indeed questionable and fans were less than excited about some of the modifications, some avoidable some not, but yet again it has not disappointed. If anything it is time for us fans to get together and make sure non-fans start to enjoy this. Especially if you know it's their sort of thing and preferably before anything can get spoiled for them. It's going to be hard for them to follow up after this series specifically because many of people's favourite characters are now either dead or no longer in Westeros. But it's time once again to wait for a year and have faith that the creators, cast, and crew can make the next series just as unforgettable as this one.
